instruction: What kinds of spectra were used to model the elimination of carbon nanocomplexes from the body via neural networks?
Output: The spectra used to model the elimination of carbon nanocomplexes from the body via neural networks were optical absorption and fluorescence spectra of nanocomposites containing carbon dots (CD) and the anticancer drug doxorubicin (Dox) in urine.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were employed in the related study of controlling the removal of carbon nanocomplexes?
Output: The spectral feature processing methods employed in the study of controlling the removal of carbon nanocomplexes were optical absorption and fluorescence spectra analysis, as well as principal component analysis (PCA).

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the accuracy of monitoring CD and Dox excretion in the related study of controlling the removal of carbon nanocomplexes?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the accuracy of monitoring CD and Dox excretion is the mean absolute error (MAE). The study states that the sensing technique allows controlling the excretion of CD and Dox with mean absolute errors of 43.8 and 20.9 渭g/L, respectively.

instruction: How were multilayer perceptrons used in the study to model the elimination of carbon nanocomplexes from the body via neural networks?
Output: Multilayer perceptrons were used in the study to decode the optical absorption and fluorescence spectra of nanocomposites containing carbon dots (CD) and doxorubicin (Dox) in urine. These spectral data were used to determine the concentrations of CD and Dox in the studied samples. By training the multilayer perceptrons with the spectral data, the researchers were able to model the process of elimination of the nanocomplexes components from the body.

instruction: Can the sensing technique developed in the related study using neural networks be used to control the removal of carbon nanocomplexes from the body and determine the concentrations of carbon dots and doxorubicin in urine?
Output: Yes, the sensing technique developed in the related study using neural networks can be used to control the removal of carbon nanocomplexes from the body and determine the concentrations of carbon dots and doxorubicin in urine. The study utilized optical absorption and fluorescence spectra of nanocomposites in urine to model the elimination process. These spectral data were decoded using multilayer perceptrons to determine the concentrations of carbon dots and doxorubicin in the samples. Additionally, principal component analysis was employed to increase the accuracy of monitoring. The results showed that the sensing technique had mean absolute errors of 43.8 and 20.9 渭g/L for controlling the excretion of carbon dots and doxorubicin, respectively, which are comparable to similar values of analogues.
